item.title: TikTok Strikes Deal to Create New U.S. Entity and Loosen App’s Ties to China
item.description: The Chinese parent company of the popular video app said a group of non-Chinese investors would create an American TikTok to avoid a federal ban.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Emmett Lindner

item.title: Here’s Who Just Bought TikTok
item.description: Several big companies and investment firms are part of the new American TikTok. Many have ties to one another and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times

item.title: Will I Have to Download a New TikTok App? And Other Big Questions About The Deal.
item.description: The popular short form video app has a new corporate structure in the United States, which could result in some changes for the 200 million Americans who use TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: It is unclear how much, if anything, will change for TikTok’s 200 million American users.

item.title: Jack Smith Testifies in House Hearing About Trump Investigations
item.description: The former special prosecutor argued a case he was never allowed to in court: that President Trump “engaged in criminal activity” that undermined democracy.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the special prosecutor who twice indicted Donald J. Trump, at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: Takeaways From Jack Smith’s Testimony on Trump Investigations
item.description: In his remarks, the former special counsel repeatedly denied that he had acted out of partisan animus and bemoaned the Trump administration’s efforts to go after the president’s perceived enemies.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the former special counsel, urged the lawmakers on Thursday to stand up for the rule of the law.

item.title: D.H.S. Cited Foreign Students’ Writings and Protests Before Their Arrests
item.description: Documents unsealed by a federal judge on Thursday include dossiers that investigators prepared on pro-Palestinian student activists before they were targeted for deportation.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio approved the revocation of visas for five international students last year.

item.title: Immigration Agents Detain 5-Year-Old Boy in Minnesota, Prompting Outrage
item.description: A photo showed a boy with an oversized hat and Spider-Man backpack being held next to a vehicle as his father was detained. A Homeland Security spokeswoman said the man had fled and left the child.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sonia A. Rao
item.media:description: Immigration agents have been circling schools in Columbia Heights, Minn., and following school buses, according to the school superintendent, Zena Stenvik.

item.title: Chicago Jury Acquits Immigrant Accused in Bovino Murder-for-Hire Trial
item.description: Prosecutors said a Chicago carpenter had offered a bounty for killing Gregory Bovino, a Border Patrol official. Defense lawyers said he was just sharing a social media post.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino, center, has become the face of the Trump administration’s aggressive immigration enforcement tactics.

item.title: White House Posts Altered Photo Showing Arrested Minnesota Protester Crying
item.description: The New York Times ran the image posted by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, as well as the one posted by the White House through an A.I. detection system. It concluded that the White House’s version showed signs of manipulation.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu, Alan Feuer and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: Nekima Levy Armstrong after speaking at an anti-ICE rally in St. Paul, Minn., on Monday. The Justice Department said on Thursday morning that it had taken her into custody, accusing her of helping to interrupt a church service in St. Paul.

item.title: Trump Rescinds Canada’s Invitation to Join His ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The president appeared to be lashing out in response to stark, high-profile remarks by Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada that rejected Mr. Trump’s efforts to dismantle the international order.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Europe’s Leaders Scramble to Find a Path Forward With Trump
item.description: Leaders from across the European Union held an emergency summit in Brussels to discuss Greenland and, more broadly, their fragile relationship with America.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Trump’s Reversal on Greenland Still Leaves Europe on Edge
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin, editor at large of DealBook, describes how leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos remain on edge after President Trump, for now, backed down from threats of using tariffs or military force to gain Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Rebecca Suner, Coleman Lowndes and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Zelensky Laces Into Europe, Saying It Must Step Up or Be Left Behind
item.description: The Ukrainian leader’s speech in Davos, Switzerland, was one of his most scathing critiques of his closest allies.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a blunt speech in Davos, Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: Mark Carney Says Firmly That ‘Canada Doesn’t Live Because of the United States’
item.description: The Canadian prime minister spoke after returning from the World Economic Forum where he urged middle powers to team up in resisting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada at a news conference in Quebec City on Thursday.

item.title: Are You Aging Well? 4 Simple Tests to Find Out.
item.description: They can’t guarantee future health, but they can tell you the trajectory you’re on.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times

item.title: House Passes Spending Package Over Democratic Revolt on ICE
item.description: Approval of the package, which would fund a wide swath of government agencies, brings Congress closer to meeting a Jan. 30 funding deadline.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis this month, the week after an ICE agent fatally shot Renee Good. Democrats in the House had said they would not vote for legislation that provided funding for ICE, at least not without major changes.

item.title: National Park Service Dismantles Slavery Exhibit in Philadelphia
item.description: The exhibit memorialized nine people enslaved by George Washington. The Park Service said it was being removed in accordance with a directive from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: An outdoor exhibit on slavery at Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia in October. The National Park Service has taken down the exhibit.

item.title: Trump to Expand ‘Mexico City’ Abortion Rule to Include D.E.I. and Gender
item.description: The policy has traditionally been aimed at keeping organizations that receive U.S. tax dollars from performing or promoting abortion as a method of family planning.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump both reinstated and expanded the “Mexico City policy” in January 2017. His administration is set to broaden the policy again.

item.title: E.P.A. Revives Plan to End Testing on Animals by 2035
item.description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, revived a plan created during the first Trump administration to end the testing of chemicals on mammals.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Ryan M. Kelly/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Trump administration’s goal has been to move faster to adopt alternatives to animal testing, like computer programs. But experts say methods like computer models do not produce the same level of information.

item.title: U.S. Winter Storm Forecast to Bring Menacing Mix of Snow, Ice and Cold
item.description: Half the U.S. population will likely see some effect from the sprawling storm that will move across the country this weekend, meteorologists said.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones

item.title: New York Could See Its Biggest Snowfall in Years
item.description: The National Weather Service warned of “considerable disruption to transportation and daily life” from Sunday into Monday.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

item.title: How a Major Winter Storm This Weekend Could Affect Your Travel Plans
item.description: Ice, sleet and possibly significant snowfall are threatening to snarl travel in much of the eastern U.S. starting on Friday. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: Ronald Reagan National Airport, near Washington, is one of dozens of airports that could experience delays this weekend.

item.title: Why iPhone and Android Weather Apps Are Freaking Out About Winter Storm Forecasts
item.description: A foot of snow in New York? Two feet? Well, it’s complicated.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones
item.media:description: At one point on Wednesday morning, Apple’s weather app was predicting up to 17 inches of snow in New York on Sunday, while other forecast sources were suggesting far less. By Thursday evening, the app was predicting eight to 10 inches of snow.

item.title: Five Fronts in Trump’s Culture War
item.description: In the first year of his second term, President Trump has made sweeping efforts to influence the arts and media in America.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: During a White House dinner in October, President Trump showed models of a triumphal arch he is planning to build in Washington.

item.title: Nurses in New York City Say They Deserve $200,000 a Year. Here’s Why.
item.description: As a strike by health workers stretches into its second week, pay is a major issue in negotiations, even if it’s not discussed much on the picket line.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein and Patrick McGeehan
item.media:description: Nearly 15,000 nurses went on strike against several of New York City’s biggest hospitals on Jan. 12.

item.title: Big Insurers Try to Shift Blame for High Health Costs to Hospitals and Drug Makers
item.description: At two congressional hearings, lawmakers slammed executives of major companies, saying they were failing to rein in the cost of medical care for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
item.media:description: Stephen Hemsley, chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, left, defended insurers’ practices, along with other companies’ executives, during congressional hearings on Thursday.

item.title: No Beer for You: How British Pubs Fought a Tax Increase
item.description: More than 1,400 pubs declared a ban on Labour lawmakers in response to a plan to raise business rates significantly. The move got attention, and results.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Landlord Andy Lennox at his pub, The Old Thatch, earlier this month.

item.title: Questions for Alex Honnold Before He Tries to Climb a Skyscraper in Taipei
item.description: Alex Honnold again will be ascending without ropes. In an interview he considers the impact on his family if something were to go wrong.
item.dc:creator: Adam Skolnick
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Honnold will try to climb a 1,667-foot skyscraper in Taiwan, without ropes, in an event scheduled to stream live on Netflix.

item.title: Oscar Snubs and Surprises: ‘Sinners’ Makes History, ‘Wicked’ Withers
item.description: Ariana Grande, Chase Infiniti and Paul Mescal were shut out, but voters made room for Delroy Lindo, Kate Hudson and “F1.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: 2026 Oscar Nominations: See the Full List
item.description: The movies competing for the 98th Academy Awards. The ceremony will air on March 15.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez and Kellina Moore
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
Little Amelie or the Character of Rain (Movie)

item.title: NATO as We Know It Is Coming to an End, and That’s OK
item.description: Europe has a chance to step out of America’s shadow.
item.dc:creator: Rajan Menon
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: Latin Americans Love the Right. Can You Blame Them?
item.description: The right is ascendant in Latin America. How long will it last?
item.dc:creator: Michael Reid

item.title: F.A.A. Says Helicopter Restrictions Imposed After D.C. Crash Will Stay
item.description: The agency said that expanding the restrictions and making them permanent were urgent steps for avoiding another crash.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: The new rule for Ronald Reagan National Airport sets strict limits on what “essential operations” could be excepted from the airspace restrictions.

item.title: Dallas County Exonerates Black Man Who Was Executed in 1956
item.description: An all-white jury convicted Tommy Lee Walker of rape and murder, relying on inadmissible evidence and a coerced confession that he immediately recanted, county officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Barron Trump Called U.K. Police After Witnessing Woman ‘Getting Beat Up’ on Video Call
item.description: The details of an emergency call made by President Trump’s youngest son to the London police last year emerged during a trial this week.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barron Trump at President Trump’s inaugural parade in Washington, D.C., in January last year, days after his phone call to the London police.

item.title: James Bernard, a Founding Editor of a Hip-Hop ‘Bible,’ Dies at 58
item.description: One of the most influential voices of the seminal magazine The Source, he chronicled rap’s rise and its explosion into the cultural mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
